headline.main: I'd Run 10 Miles (Cough! Cough!) for a Camel

keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION
keywords.name: organizations

docs.lead_paragraph: JOHN E. PLEW took up both exercise and Marlboro Reds when he was 16. He developed a habit of running four miles most weekdays and at least six each Saturday and Sunday. And in the following years, despite smoking a pack a day, this 42-year-old manager at IBM competed in more than 10 triathlons and finished a marathon in less than four hours. ''You're always justifying your existence,'' said Mr. Plew, who lives in Pleasant Valley, N.Y. ''People I ran with routinely couldn't believe I smoked. People I was out with drinking and smoking couldn't believe it when I'd say, 'I'm going to run seven miles tomorrow.'''
docs.snippet: Exercise may tip the balance in a smoker's life a little toward the healthy side.
